div.p: Amination of bulky ketones, particularly in (R)-configuration, is an attractive chemical conversion, however known -transaminases (ω-TAs) show insufficient performances. By applying two screening methods we discovered 10 amine transaminases from the class III ω-TAs family, 38-76% identical to homologues. We present examples of such enzymes preferring bulky ketones over keto acids and aldehydes with stringent (S)selectivity. We also report representatives from the class III ω-TAs capable of converting (R) and (S) amines and bulky ketones, and one converting amines with longer alkyl substituents.

The preference for bulky ketones was associated with the presence of a hairpin region proximal to the conserved Arg414 and residues conforming and close to it. The outward orientation of Arg414 additionally favored the conversion of (R)-amines. This configuration was also found to favor the utilization of putrescine as amine donor, so that class III ω-TAs with Arg414 in outward orientation may participate in vivo in the catabolism of putrescine.

The positioning of the conserved Ser231 contributes also to the preference of amines with longer alkyl substituents. Optimal temperatures for activity ranged from 45 to 65 °C, and a few enzymes retained ≥ 50% of their activity in water-soluble solvents (up to 50% (v/v)).

Hence, our results will pave the way to design, in the future, new class III ω-TAs converting bulky ketones and (R)-amines for production of high value products, and screen those converting putrescine. IMPORTANCE Amine transaminases of the class III ω-TAs are key enzymes for modification of chemical building blocks, but finding those capable of converting bulky ketones and (R)-amines is still challenging. Here, by an extensive analysis of the substrate spectra of 10 class III ω-TAs, we identified a number of residues playing a role in determining the access and positioning of bulky ketones, bulky amines, and (R)-and (S)amines as well as of environmentally relevant polyamines, particularly, putrescine. The results presented can significantly expand future opportunities for designing (R)-specific class III ω-TAs to convert valuable bulky ketones and amines as well as deepening the knowledge into the polyamine catabolic pathways.

Transaminases (EC 2.6.1.x), also called aminotransferases, are versatile enzymes with industrial potential (1). They catalyze asymmetric amine transfer reactions between an amine and a ketone, aldehyde or keto-acid, and thus are key enzymes to produce building blocks for drug discovery and chemical biology. All transaminases reported so far require pyridoxal-5'-phosphate (PLP) as coenzyme, which serves as a molecular shuttle for ammonia and electrons between the amine donor and the acceptor in a catalytic cycle. Firstly, the amine group from the amine donor binds to the enzyme, pyridoxamine-5'-phosphate (PMP) is then formed from PLP, and the amine donor is released as a keto product. Afterwards, PMP transfers the amine group to the acceptor, and PMP is regenerated to PLP, closing the catalytic cycle. Based on their amino acid sequences transaminases are classified in six groups (classes I to VI) (1), with class III covering the so-called ω-transaminases (ω-TAs).
Within the ω-TAs, the class of amine transaminases (ATAs) has industrial relevance as they have been used for the preparation of optically pure amines starting from the corresponding ketones (1,2).

In an ideal scenario, functional screening with genomics and metagenomics techniques would allow the identification of a new generation of microbial biocatalysts, including ATAs of the class III ω-TAs (3)(4)(5)(6). However, extensive bioprospecting by metagenomics was only rarely successful (5), despite the growing number of sequences available in public databases (7). Indeed, only three class III ω-TAs have been identified by metagenomics techniques, however, by applying sequence homology-based techniques rather than functional methods (8). These enzymes showed a poor performance with ketones as compared with aldehydes and keto acids. As an example, the conversion of acetone was measured to be less than 0.04% relative to that for 2-oxobutyrate and propionaldehyde (8), which were the preferred keto acid and aldehyde substrates, respectively. The thermodynamic limitation for the amination of ketones is a common characteristic of ω-TAs (9). For instance, the kcat/KM of the ω-TA from Ochrobactrum arthropi for acetophenone was only 0.0004% relative to that for pyruvate (10). Also, ω-TAs from Parococcus denitrificans and Chromobacterium violaceum showed from 0.015% to 0.083% relative activity for ketones compared to α-keto acids and aldehydes (9). This prompted the research to create, by active site engineering, ω-TAs variants displaying improved capacity for the synthesis of chiral amines from bulky ketones. By applying this procedure, a 105-fold activity improvement for the conversion of butyrophenone was on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from achieved for the ω-TA from O. arthropi, although the relative activity as compared to aldehyde was still low (from 1.4 to 11.3% relative activity) (10).

Finding new ω-TAs displaying high capability for the conversion of ketones, in combination with good stability and preferably stringent (R) or (S)-selectivity (11)(12)(13), is thus a priority to synthesize pharmaceutically valuable chiral amines (9). However, their discovery is limited most likely due to a lack of suitable screening methods at large scale.

Recently, new assays for high throughput screening of ATAs in liquid or solid-phase were described (14,15). By adapting these methods to screen a large collection of clone libraries generated from environmental DNA of diverse origins we successfully identified 10 genes encoding presumptive ATAs of the class III ω-TAs family. These genes were expressed in fusion to poly-histidine (His) affinity tags, purified by immobilized metal affinity chromatography, and characterized. The results presented here illustrate the benefits of the methods herein applied to screen for ω-TAs using metagenomics. The extensive analysis of their substrate spectra allows identifying those capable of converting bulky ketones and bulky amines as well as environmentally relevant amines such as putrescine. Finally, the application of sequence and 3-dimensional model analyses shed new lights on the molecular determinants of their substrate specificity and stereochemistry. The present study may help future bioprospecting and engineering programs to identify and design class III ω-TAs family proteins converting bulky ketones and bulky amines with either stringent (R) or (S) stereo-specificity.

div.head: RESULTS
div.p: Gene selection by naïve screens. Recently, a large set of metagenomic fosmid libraries from microbial communities inhabiting 28 geographically distinct environmental sites have been created and subjected to naïve screen for esterase activity (16). In accordance with biological diversity and activity success rate, libraries from microbial communities inhabiting 10 of these sites (for details see Experimental Section) were chosen as starting points for screening new ω-TAs encoding sequences. We applied to all libraries two distinct naïve agar-based screen methods utilizing the two amine donors 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine and oxylylenediamine hydrochloride (Fig. S1), which after transfer reactions render a colored product than can be identified by visual inspection (14,15). About half a million pCCFOS1 on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from fosmid clones (nearly 18 Gbp) from libraries generated from environmental DNA and 4400 plasmid-based (pCR-XL-TOPO) clones from Pseudomonas oleovorans genomic DNA library were screened for ATA activity using both agar-based screens. We identified a total of 10 positive clones active against 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine, 3 of which were also active against o-xylylenediamine hydrochloride. They were recovered from clone libraries created from two chronically polluted marine sediment samples, a beach acidic pool and the P. oleovorans genome (legend to Table S1) (16)(17)(18). This means a ratio of circa 1 positive per 50000 clones tested; note that this ratio is an indicator of the abundance of enzyme activities in metagenomes (5,19). The 10 positive fosmid/plasmid inserts were fully sequenced by Illumina MiSeq Sequencing System. From the sequence data, 10 candidate genes encoding putative ω-TAs, one per insert, were identified. S1, the deduced molecular mass and estimated isoelectric point (pI) values for the amino acid sequences encoding the 10 ω-TAs (TR1 to TR10) ranged from 48.4 to 50.8 kDa and from 5.4 to 6.1, respectively. A comprehensive analysis of the TBLASTX results (20) indicated that putative proteins exhibited amino acid sequence identities ranging from 84 to 100% to uncharacterized homologous proteins in non-redundant public databases and from 35.7 to 60.7% in Protein Data Bank (PDB). As determined by Matcher (EMBOSS package), the pairwise amino acid sequence identity between the 10 selected sequences ranged from circa 33% to 99% (see Table S2A). TR3 and TR7 (98.9%), TR4 and TR5 (94.5%) and TR9 and TR10 (92.9%) shared the highest sequence similarity. Sequence analysis and TBLASTX (20) categorize all sequences within the class III ω-TAs family (21). It is interesting to note that the naïve assays employed led to the identification of only class III ω-TAs and none of the other 5 groups referred to as classes I, II, IV-VI (1). It may be due to the fact that compared to ATAs from other groups, ω-TAs transfer an amino group from an amine donor onto a carbonyl moiety of an amine acceptor, in which at least one of the two substances is not an α-amino acid or an α-keto acid (1). Any of these substrates was used in the naïve screens, which may explain why the screening with the two amine donors 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine and oxylylenediamine hydrochloride produced a bias towards the section of class III ω-TAs.

div.head: Analysis of candidates at the protein sequence level. As shown in Table
div.p: Taken together, these data suggest a large divergence at the sequence level within the identified class III ω-TAs sequences, and that the diversity was not dominated by a on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from particular type of protein or highly similar clusters of proteins but consists of diverse nonredundant 10 ω-TA sequences. Phylogenetic binning (22,23) of sequences encoding presumptive class III ω-TAs further revealed they most likely originated from bacteria of the Rhodobacteraceae family (5 sequences), and the Pseudomonas (3 sequences), Acidihalobacter (1 sequence) and Amphritea (1 sequence) genera (see Supporting Results and Fig. S2).

Recombinant protein production. The 10 candidates were cloned into pBXCH or pRhokHi-2 (with C-terminal His-tags), or pBHXN3 (N-terminal His-tags) expression vectors (Fig. S1), allowing high expression yields for genes of environmental and microbial origins (16,24,25). E. coli MC1061 (when using pBXCH and pBHXN3 vectors) and DH5α (for pRhokHi-2) were used as expression hosts. The preferred construct design for each enzyme was selected on the basis of obtained protein yield which is out of the scope of the present study and thus not shown. The average yield of the ω-TAs in E. coli heterologous expression systems was approximately 32 mg purified protein per liter of culture. The 10 hexahistidinetagged candidates were purified from lysed cells by immobilized metal affinity chromatography using Ni-NTA technology (Fig. S3). The substrate profile and properties of purified ω-TAs were further analyzed.

Acceptor profiling: preference for bulky ketones. The acceptor profiling was performed by adapting the colorimetric liquid assay reported by Baud et al. (14) with minor modifications (see Experimental Section). We used one primary amine donor (2-(4nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine) and a set of 18 chemically and structurally distinct aldehydes, ketones and keto acids as amine acceptors (see Scheme S1). Alkyl ketones of different length and large aromatic ketones and aldehydes were also included, since a larger group adjacent to the aldehyde or ketone group increases the difficulty of amine transfer. Reaction mixtures obtained in all cases were analyzed by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) (see Experimental Section), and the existence of reaction products was confirmed in each case (see Supporting Results).

The relative (%) specific activity referred to best substrate of all 10 ω-TAs per each of the 18 acceptors is summarized in Fig. 1; for specific activity (U g -1 protein) raw data see Table S2B. We first observed that according to best acceptor, TR1 was also the least active enzyme with a maximum specific activity of 95.7 U g -1 , compared to the other ω-TAs whose values on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from range from 972 U g -1 to 179 U g -1 (Table S2B). The specific activity for best substrates is in the range of previously reported -TAs (12,26).

Regarding acceptor range, only 6 out of 18 amine acceptors were converted by all 10 ω-TAs (Fig. 1). We found that TR1 was characterized by a restricted acceptor spectrum being only capable of using as acceptors the keto acids glyoxylic acid, levulinic acid and αketoglutaric acid (non-preferred acceptors), and to much higher extend the aldehydes hexanal (preferred acceptor) and benzaldehyde and the ketone 2-hexanone. No capacity of TR1 to use any of the other linear and bulky ketones tested was detected under the assay conditions. All other 9 ω-TAs showed broader acceptor spectra and were characterized by a significantly higher preference for ketones compared to aldehydes and keto acids. Thus, on the basis of specific activity determinations (U g -1 ), the relative activities for the amine transfer to best accepted ketone as compared to the preferred aldehydes or keto acids was found to be 50.4% (for TR1), 96.1% (for TR2), 9.0% (for TR3), 90.3% (for TR4), 112.5% (for TR5), 1.1% (for TR6), 84.3% (for TR7), 14.9% (for TR8), 173.4% (for TR9), and 142.8% (for TR10), as measured at 40ºC and pH 7.5 (see Table S2B). These percentages are significantly higher than those observed for previously reported ω-TAs (below 0.083%) (8)(9)(10).

Preferred acceptors for most ω-TAs were hexanal, benzaldehyde or the bulky ketone 1-N-Boc-3-pyrrolidinone, depending on the transaminase (Fig. 1). Other bulky ketones, particularly 2-acetylpyridine and 2-acetylpyrazine, were well accepted by all ω-TAs, albeit they were not the preferred acceptors. Concerning the use of aliphatic ketones as acceptors, we found that an increase in the side chain length resulted in lower conversion (2-hexanone > 2-heptanone > 2-nonanone). As shown in Fig. 1, bulky ketones were converted at similar or higher level as compared to aliphatic ketones and aldehydes. Concerning the use of ketoacids, it is noticeable the higher preference of TR6 and TR8 for glyoxylic acid, compared to other ω-TAs.

The similar acceptor profiles for TR9 and TR10 (Fig. 1) agree with their 93% identity at the amino acid sequence level (Table S2A). However, TR3 and TR7 which share 99% identity differed in the capacity to use multiple acceptors, which was particularly noticeable for their capacity to use 1-N-Boc-3-pyrrolidinone (rel. act. of 1.6% for TR3 and 84.31% for TR7) and glyoxylic acid (rel. act. of 28.8% for TR3 and 1.04% for TR7). TR4 and TR5 being 94.5% identical did show only appreciable difference for the conversion of 4-phenyl-2-butanone (rel. act. of on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from 31.7% for TR4 and 3.3% for TR5); 1-indanone was only converted by TR5 albeit at significantly low rel. act. (0.93%) compared to best acceptor. It is particularly noticeably that, excluding TR1 which was unable to use 1-N-Boc-3-pyrrolidinone, TR3 and TR8 did show a significantly low relative specific activity for this acceptor (1.6% for TR3 and 0.3% for TR8) compared to all other ω-TAs, for which this was one of the preferred acceptors (from 84.3 to 100% rel. act.). Donor profiling: preference for bulky amines. The ω-TAs were examined using benzaldehyde as ketone acceptor and a set of 14 chemically and structurally distinct amine donors (see Scheme S2), including 4 pairs of enantiomers and the inexpensive isopropyl amine (Fig. 1; for raw data see Table S2C). Instead of using the common gas chromatography method for detecting transamination products (12), we adapted the colorimetric assay described by Baud et al. ( 14) Briefly, we detected the amount of benzaldehyde that remained after the reaction compared to control reactions in the absence of amine donor and in the absence of enzymes (see Scheme S2 and Experimental section). The reaction mixtures obtained in all cases were also analyzed by ESI-MS (see Experimental Section), and the formation of reaction products confirmed (see Supporting Results).

We first observed that using benzaldehyde and the preferred amine donor, the maximum activity ranges from 22.8 to 841.5 U g -1 (Table S2C), which is in the range of other reported ω-TAs (12,28). Regarding specificity, mayor differences in the capacity to use the amine donors were noticed, although all of them were characterized by an ample amine spectrum (Fig. 1).

Only 4 out of 14 amine donors were converted by all 10 ω-TAs, including (S)-(+)-2aminononane, and the bulky amines 1-methyl-3-phenylpropylamine, 1-(4trifluoromethylphenyl)ethylamine, and 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)ethanamine, which were among the preferred amines in most cases. The other 10 amines were distinctly converted, highlighting the following major differences in the capacity to convert bulky amines. TR1

was the only one using 1-(2-pyridyl)ethylamine and 2-methyl-1-phenylpropan-1-amine as amine donors; the capacity to use these bulky amines contrasts with the low capacity of TR1 to use bulky ketones as acceptors (Fig. 1). To date, only few (S)-selective ω-TAs, but not (R)selective ones, were identified capable of accepting a propyl group of amine substrates in the so-called S pocket (29). The fact that TR1, which converts (R) and (S) amines (see below), was capable of using 2-methyl-1-phenylpropan-1-amine as amine donor, which contains an isopropyl group, is thus an unusual feature for this enzyme. Benzylamine and (S)-(-)-α-on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from methylbenzylamine were only donor substrates for TR1 and TR2, (S)-1-(4nitrophenyl)ethylamine were not accepted by TR9 and TR10, and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-1naphthylamine was not converted by TR8. Concerning the use of aliphatic amines, we found that larger amines were preferred. Indeed, all ω-TAs convert (S)-(+)-2-aminononane, but only 3 (TR3, TR5 and TR7) out of 10 converted the shorter (S)-(+)-2-aminohexane. It is particularly noticeable that all, but TR1, TR9 and TR10, were capable of using isopropyl amine as donor substrate, although this was not the preferred donor (Fig. 1).

In agreement with their high sequence identity (Table S2A), TR9 and TR10 showed similar donor profile. TR3 and TR7 (99% identical) were capable of using 10 amine donors, with a notable difference in their capacity to convert 1-(4-methoxyphenyl)ethanamine which was not converted by TR3 but was one of the preferred donor for TR7 (rel. act. of 96%). Finally, the 94.5% identical TR4 and TR5 converted 10 amines with major differences only noticed in the conversion of (S)-(+)-2-aminohexane which was not converted by TR4 but was one of the preferred donor for TR5 (rel. act. of 80.3%).

div.head: Sequence similarity and genome neighbor network analysis. Sequence Similarity
div.p: Network (SSN) of TR1-TR10 sequences was performed with the collection of aminotransferase class-III of the InterPro database (IPR005814; 55400 entries). The network is shown in Fig. 2AB, where each node represent entries with 60% or higher sequence similarity and the lengths of the edges correlate with the dissimilarity of the connected sequences represented by the nodes (organic layout). Although the pairwise amino acid sequence identity between the 10 selected sequences ranged from circa 33% to 99%, they were all located in a central cluster in color. A secondary SSN built from the 500 first BLAST against each sequence query (Fig. S4A) was used for building a Genome Neighborhood Network (GNN). Using a window of 5 ORFs upstream and downstream the candidate TR1-TR10 genes, the genomic context of each of the target sequences was inferred.

GNN for cluster TR2, TR9, and TR10 is shown in Fig. S4B. The GNN was highly homogenous with regards to the ORF architecture (Fig. 2C), consisting of a putrescine binding periplasmic protein (PotF), a spermidine/putrescine import ATP-binding protein (PotA), a putrescine transport permease, a Gln-synt_C (glutamine synthetase) likely to act as a gamma-glutamyl-putrescine synthetase which ligates glutamate and putrescine, and an aminotransferase (Fig. 2C). Together, TR2, TR9, and TR10 might be involved in the catabolism on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from of polyamines, more specifically putrescine (Fig. 3). GNN for cluster TR6 (Fig. S4B) and ORF architecture (Fig. 2C) revealed that despite the pattern variations, the same elements are present: the transporter proteins, Gln-syntC, the aminotransferase and an oxidase mostly related to glycine/D-amino acid oxidase or gamma-glutamyl-putrescine oxidoreductase. In summary, TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 seem to be related to putrescine catabolism (Fig. S4D). In this pathway, the only transaminase occurs after obtaining 4-aminobutanoate (also known as GABA), which serves as substrate for the transaminase (Fig. S4C). However, it is plausible that putrescine can also be a direct substrate for the transaminase; this is an alternative catabolic pathway that generates glutamate and 4-aminobutanal that is further oxidized to GABA (Fig. 3).

The GNN clusters (Fig. S4B) and genomic contexts (Fig. 2C) for the other transaminases (TR1, TR3-TR5, TR7 and TR8) do show many common elements, but there are also significant variations. The major difference is that both the genes encoding putrescine-ABC transporter system and the glutamate:putrescine ligase are missing, but other are present in the vicinity, including an aldehyde dehydrogenase family protein (Aldedh), an aminotransferase_3 , and another type of transporter (amino acid permease). SSN suggests that most entries corresponding to Aldedh are annotated as 5-carboxymethyl-2-hydroxymuconate dehydrogenase (tyrosine metabolism), betaine-aldehyde dehydrogenase (glycine, serine and threonine metabolism), succinate-semialdehyde dehydrogenase (putrescine and GABA degradation), gamma-glutamyl-gamma-aminobutyraldehyde dehydrogenase (putrescine catabolism), methylmalonate-semialdehyde dehydrogenase (inositol metabolism, valine, leucine and isoleucine degradation and propionate metabolism) or phenylacetaldehyde dehydrogenase (phenylalanine metabolism). Together, we may suggest that these transaminase genes are related to amino acid catabolism, but not putrescine catabolism because the absence of ABC transporter and the Gln-synt. However, the possibility that these genes are implicated in the catabolism of putrescine cannot be ruled out: the transport is through a permease different from the ABC-type, and the two aminotransferases and the Aldedh are related to the catabolism of putrescine via 4-aminobutanal and GABA.

Based on the SSN and GNN analyses, the role of TR1-TR10 in vivo in the catabolism of putrescine may be investigated. Potential substrates may be putrescine and GABA. They were tested as amine donors using benzaldehyde as acceptors.

The progress of the reaction on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from was followed by measuring the remaining amount of benzaldehyde at the end of the reaction (see Scheme S2 and Experimental section) and by ESI-MS (see Experimental Section), respectively.

The data provided in Table 1 confirmed TR1, TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 are capable of using putrescine, but not GABA, as amine donor, when using benzaldehyde as acceptor. This suggests their implication in vivo in the putrescine catabolism via formation of 4aminobutanal (Fig. 3). By contrast, TR3-TR5, TR7 and TR8 did not use putrescine or GABA as amine donor (Table 1), so that they may most likely participate in the catabolism of polyamines other than putrescine. Overall, results agree with the SSN and GNN results.

Evaluation of enantio-selectivity. The selectivity towards chiral amines was first determined by meaning of the selectivity factor calculated as the ratio of specific activity (U g -1 ) of the preferred over the non-preferred chiral amines when both (R) and (S)-amines were tested separately (see Scheme 3). It should be mentioned that these apparent values may not correspond to true selectivity or enantiomeric factors calculated when the enzyme is confronted to a racemic mixture, because the rates of transamination of the enantiomers were was determined by applying a colorimetric assay in which benzaldehyde was used as amine acceptor, as described above.

As shown in Fig. 1 and Table 2, we found that under our assay conditions 6 ω-TAs were stringently (S)-selective with no appreciable activity for any of the (R)-amines tested. TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 were capable of converting both (R)-and (S)-enantiomers of 2aminononane, with the (S)-enantiomer being preferred (Fig. 1). For these 4 ω-TAs, the selectivity factor calculated as the ratio of specific activity (U g -1 ) of the preferred ((S)-(+)-2aminononane) over the non-preferred ((R)-(-+)-2-aminononane) chiral amine ranged from 1.2 to 5.4 (Table 2). The selectivity as calculated by kinetic resolution and asymmetric synthesis and Gas Chromatography (see Scheme 3; Fig. S5), also confirm the results of the colorimetric assays (Table 2).

div.head: Downloaded from
div.p: It has been previously demonstrated that co-solvents (i.e. 30% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) can change the selectivity of ω-TAs (13). For this reason, the apparent selectivity for TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 was evaluated, by colorimetric assays, in the present of 30% DMSO, concentration at which the enzymes retain more than 67% of their activity (see below). No statistically significant changes in apparent selectivity factor were observed against (S) and
(R)-2-aminononane (data not shown).

Optimal parameters for activity. Using benzaldehyde and 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1amine as acceptor and donor, respectively, the purified ω-TAs were found to be most active at temperatures ranging from 45 to 65 °C (Fig. 4). TR3, TR6, TR7 and TR8 were the most active at the high temperature range (60-65 °C). Tolerance to organic solvents increases the industrial utility of enzymes. The amination of benzaldehyde with 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1amine was tested at different concentrations (from 5 to 50% v/v) of water miscible solvents, namely, methanol, acetonitrile, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), dimethyl acetamide (DMA), isopropanol and acetone (Fig. 5). TR2, TR4, TR5 and TR10 were most active in the presence of acetone (from 45.0 to 51.7% rel. act. at 50%), TR3 and TR6, TR7, TR9 were most active in the presence of DMSO (circa 100%, 42%, 63% and 44% rel. act. at 50%). TR8 retained more than 59% rel. act. in the presence of DMA, DMSO and isopropanol at 50%.

div.head: Molecular determinants of substrate specificity.
div.p: The extensive analysis of the substrate spectra showed a number of differences (Fig. 1), possibly a reflection of the divergence in steric constraints and active site architecture, which may help to better understand the specificity and stereochemistry of the ω-TAs herein investigated.

An extensive analysis of the key active site residues determining the substrate specificity in previously reported ω-TAs (27) through multiple sequence alignments and 3-dimensional structural models (Figs. S6-S10), was performed. This analysis was done in relation to substrate specificity data (Fig. 1). We first found that residues previously suggested to play a role in substrate recognition (27; Fig. S7) may not have a role in determining the substrate spectra and preference for bulky substrates in the 10 ω-TAs herein described (see Supporting Results). Rather, most likely, a major molecular determinant of the capacity of class III ω-TAs herein described to use as acceptors bulky ketones is the presence of a hairpin region proximal to the highly conserved Arg414 (Fig. 6), following numeration in ω-TA from

Pseudomonas putida (PDB 3A8U), an ω-TA with X-ray structure and extensively characterized on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from (27). This hairpin region is present in TR2-TR10 but not TR1 nor PDB 3A8U (Fig. 7). We hypothesize that the presence of this hairpin and the residues conforming it (Fig. 7), and the nature of 3 amino acids in the proximity, play a role in determining the orientation of the conserved Arg414, and the access and positioning of bulkier ketones to the L pocket to an extent higher than that previously though for the conserved Arg414 (27). This can be seen in TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 were the only class III ω-TA herein reported capable of converting (R)-amines, although the low selectivity cannot give access to highly optically pure amines.

In order to deepen into the possibility to design (R)-selective variants, an inspection of the literature records was firstly examined. Note that (R)-selective amine transaminases have been only reported within the PLP-dependent fold class IV -TAs, which were found by applying in silico mining approaches (29,30). Sequence alignment of TR1-TR10 sequences with sequences of (R)-selective PLP-dependent fold class IV proteins (29) revealed that any of the conserved residues implicated in the recognition of (R)-amines in those enzymes were found in any of the class III ω-TAs herein reported (Fig. S11). This suggests that residues other than those reported for class IV -TAs are determining the capacity of class III -TAs to convert (R)-amines. The analysis of sequence alignments and 3D models revealed that TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 has in common, in contrast to the other class III ω-TAs herein reported, the presence of a large pocket volume, the presence of an hairpin region close to the conserved Arg414, and the outward orientation of Arg414 (Figs. 7, Fig. S6-S8). We suggest that those structural elements, aside others yet to be determined, may be responsible of the capacity of both enantiomers to be positioned in the active site of TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10 and thus determine the capacity of such enzymes to convert (R)-amines.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: In this study we adapted two high-throughput screening methods to identify 10 class III ω-

TAs family proteins. The identified ω-TAs originated from bacteria from at least four different and divergent lineages: Pseudomonas, Acidihalobacter and Amphritea genera, and on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from Rhodobacteraceae family. ω-TAs from the Pseudomonas genus (31) and Rhodobacteraceae family (32,33) have been reported previously. However, this study examines ω-TAs derived from bacteria of the Amphritea (TR8) and Acidihalobacter (TR2) genera, which are bacterial groups rarely investigated from an enzymatic point of view (34,35). Our results suggest that the class III ω-TA (TR8) from the bacterium of the Amphritea genus is thermo-active (up to 65 °C) and stable (it retained more than 35% activity at 50% (v/v) of methanol, acetonitrile, and DMSO) and efficiently converts bulky substrates and (S)-amines. The enzyme from the bacterium of the Acidihalobacter genus was also capable of accepting bulky substrates as well as (R)-and (S)-amines. These features clearly suggest those transaminases and their bacterial origin should be considering for future chemical transformations.

Particularly noticeable was the high performance for ketones in comparison to aldehydes and keto acids, with specific activities for ketones being up to 173.4% relative to the bestaccepted aldehyde and keto acids substrates. Such preference for ketones is rarely observed for other native or engineered ω-TAs (8-10), which exemplifies the potential of bioprospecting programs to identify new such enzymes for the amination of bulky ketones.

Molecular determinants for this unusual specificity for bulky ketones were found and suggested, which included a hairpin region proximal to the highly conserved Arg414 and residues in its proximity (Fig. 7) as major determinant for the preference of bulky ketones and amines. Identifying transaminases containing this hairpin and applying rational or traditional protein engineering in the region may allow designing class III ω-TA capable of converting bulky ketones and bulky amines. The conserved Ser231 was also found as major determinant for the preference of amines with longer alkyl substituents (Fig. S7).

The present study also reported 6 class III ω-TAs with a stringent (S)-enantioselectivity. This is a common feature within most transaminases, such as the ω-TAs belonging to PLP type I fold and which are all specific towards the (S)-enantiomer of their substrates. This also accounts for class III ω-TAs (27). Interestingly, we also reported four ATAs capable of acting towards (S) and (R)-amines, with the (S) enantiomer being preferred. Note that both (S)-and (R)-selective ω-TAs have been found in distantly related families others than class III ω-TAs, namely those belonging to Pfam transaminases class IV with a PLP type IV fold (29,(36)(37)(38)(39)(40).

Compared to (S)-selective, the (R)-selective counterparts are less abundant and have been less studied. All (R)-specific class IV ω-TAs preferably convert aliphatic substrates with high on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from yield and high enantioselectivity (ee higher than 90% for (R) enantiomer), but the yields are significantly lower with aromatic substrates. Recently, the introduction of 27 mutations into a fold IV ATA allowed broadening the substrate scope towards bulky substrates (30).

Therefore, four of the enzymes here reported represent examples of class III ω-TAs family converting (R)-amines, although they also convert (S)-amines. Having a class III -TA acting towards (S)-and (R)-amines with low selectivity towards the latter may be more a disadvantage rather than an advantage as they cannot give access to highly optically pure amines. Although they are not (R)-selective, the capacity to act efficiently towards (R)-amines can be used as starting point to apply rational design and protein engineering to design (R)selective variants from the naturally occurring class III ω-TAs herein identified and possibly others. This study suggests a number of molecular determinants which may help the rational design of such enzymes. These determinants included a large active site pocket, the presence of an hairpin region close to the conserved Arg414 and the outward orientation of Arg414 (Fig. 7). Improving or even reversing the selectivity by single point mutations has been also

shown by recent examples in bibliography in other classes of ω-TA (11,13), although engineering has been shown to lead to low selectivity variants and it is not a universal effect for all substrates (11).

Taken together, this study reported examples of class III ω-TAs efficiently converting not only bulky ketones with stringent (S)-stereochemistry, but also one converting bulky ketones and bulky amines with a large alkyl substituent, and a number of those converting bulky ketones and both (R)-and (S)-amines. Four enzymes additionally retained significant activity up to 60-65 °C and five were stable in up to 50% (v/v) organic solvents. Altogether, the amine transaminases herein reported display biochemical properties that make them attractive candidates for a variety of chemical conversions and suggest future actions to design (R)-selective class III ω-TAs.

The characterization of the ten class III ω-TAs herein described allows also deepening into their participation in polyamine catabolism, namely that of putrescine, an ubiquitous and important biological molecule (41). We found that class III ω-TAs, which contained the highly conserved Arg414 in an outward conformation (TR2, TR6, TR9 and TR10; Figs. 7), were capable of degrading putrescine via formation of 4-aminobutanal (Fig. 3). Opposite, those where Arg414 was in the inward conformation (TR3-TR5, TR7 and TR8; Fig. 7) were not able to on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from degrade putrescine. TR1 was also capable of degrading putrescine. Its sequence differs from those of TR2-TR10 by the absence of a hairpin region proximal to Arg414 (Fig. 7) causing an inward configuration of this residue, which is slightly differentially oriented compared to that in TR3-TR5, TR7 and TR8. Therefore, the orientation of the highly conserved Arg414 may be not only used as indicator of the capacity of class III ω-TAs to degrade bulky ketones, bulky amines and (R)-and (S)-amines, but also as indicator of the capacity to degrade putrescine. Note that in previously reported class III ω-TAs the conserved Arg414 has been also shown to adopt different conformations, inward or outward (27). This orientation has been implicated in the recognition of carboxylate groups of keto acids and in determining the size of the large pocket (28). However, no environmental implication was suggested for the different orientation of the conserved Arg414. In this study, we found that the different orientation of the conserved Arg414 cannot, per se, be directly linked to the distinct capacity to convert keto acids over ketones as it was previously suggested (27,28), as enzymes in which Arg414 is similarly oriented show marked differences in substrate preference and their capacity to use keto acids (Fig. 1). Rather, we found that the orientation can be linked to the capacity to degrade environmentally important biological polyamines (41), such as putrescine as shown in this study (Fig. 3).

div.head: General experimental procedures.
div.p: All chemicals used for enzymatic tests were of the purest grade available and were purchased from Fluka-Aldrich-Sigma Chemical Co. (St Louis, MO, USA). E. coli strains MC1061, a generous gift from Eric Geertsma, and DH5α strain were used for expressing TR1-TR10.
Naïve screens. The fosmid libraries used in the present study derived from 9

geographically distinct marine samples. They include samples from Milazzo and Messina harbor (Sicily, Italy) (16,18,42), Ancona harbor (Ancona, Italy) with uric acid and ammonium amendments (17), Priolo Gargallo harbor (Syracuse, Italy) (18), Arenzano harbour (Ligurian Sea, Genoa, Italy) (18), beach acidic pool in Vulcano Island (Italy) (18,42), El Max site (Alexandria, Egypt) (18), Bizerte lagoon (Tunisia) (18), and Gulf of Aqaba (Red Sea, Jordan) (18). In all cases, DNA extraction and preparation of pCCFOS1 fosmid libraries were performed as described elsewhere (16,18,42). A genomic library of P. oleovorans DSM 1045 on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from was constructed as described with minor modifications (43). Briefly, genomic DNA of P.

oleovorans DSM 1045 was isolated and fragmented by sonication, appropriately-sized fragments were then collected by gel extraction and end-repaired (44). 5' Phosphates were removed by alkaline phosphatase (FastAP, Thermo Scientific) followed by DNA precipitation. 3' Adenine overhangs were added by Taq polymerase and cloned into the pCR-XL-TOPO vector according to the manufacturer's recommendation (TOPO® XL PCR Cloning Kit, Invitrogen). The recombinant plasmids were then transformed to E. coli TOP10 cells by electroporation.

Clones were scored for the ability to perform transamination reactions by adapting a colorimetric assay (14). Briefly, the method is based on the use of 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1amine as an amine donor that when converted into the corresponding aldehyde and subsequent deprotonation would give a highly conjugated structure with absorbance in the UV region and an orange/red precipitate. Fosmid clones were plated onto large ( 22 on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Positive clones containing presumptive transaminases were selected, and their DNA inserts were sequenced using a MiSeq Sequencing System (Illumina, San Diego, USA) with a 2 × 150-bp sequencing kit. Upon completion of sequencing, the reads were quality-filtered and assembled to generate non-redundant meta-sequences, and genes predicted and annotated as described previously (45). The sequences of the inserts of the plasmids for candidates derived from P. oleovorans genome data (46) after terminal-sequencing of the plasmid insert (LGC Genomics GmbH, Berlin, Germany).

div.head: Gene expression.
div.p: Two expression platforms were used. Codon-optimized synthetic versions of the TR1 and TR3-TR8 candidate genes were synthesized by GenScript (Hong Kong) and delivered in a customized pUC plasmid. These constructs were dissolved in sterile water upon arrival and used as delivery plasmid for sub-cloning by fragment exchange (FX) into the expression vectors pBXCH or pBXNH3 using E. coli MC1061 as a host (24,47). Candidate genes for TR2, TR9 and TR10 were amplified from clonal DNA using genespecific primers containing overhangs with restriction sites (NdeI/ XhoI for TR2; NdeI/ HindIII for TR9 and TR10) and cloned into expression vector pRhokHi-2 using E. coli MC1061 as a host (25).

div.head: Recombinant protein purification.
div.p: All recombinant proteins were expressed with Histags and purified as follows. Briefly, selected E. coli clones that were found to convert the screening substrates were grown at 37 °C on solid Luria Bertani (LB) agar medium supplemented with the appropriate antibiotics (for 100 µg ml -1 pBXCH or pBXNH3 or 30 µg ml -1 kanamycin for pRhokHi-2). Single colonies were picked and used to inoculate 10 ml of LB broth supplemented with the appropriate antibiotic in a 0.25-liter flask. The cultures were then incubated at 37 °C and 200 rpm overnight. Afterwards, 10 mL of this culture was used to inoculate 0.5 liter of LB medium plus antibiotic, which was then incubated to an OD600nm of approximately 0.7 (ranging from 0.55 to 0.75) at 37 °C. TR1, TR3-TR8 protein expression was induced by adding L-arabinose to a final concentration of approx. 0.1%, followed by incubation for 16 h at 16 °C. TR2, TR9, TR10 were constitutively expressed using the same conditions (no inductor needed). In all cases, the cells were harvested by centrifugation at 5000 × g for 15 min to yield a pellet of 2-3 g (wet weight). The wet cell pellet was frozen at -on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from 86 °C overnight, thawed and resuspended in 15 ml of 40 mM 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES), pH 7.0. Lysonase Bioprocessing Reagent (Novagen, Darmstadt, Germany) was added (4 µl g -1 wet cells) and incubated for 60 min on ice with rotating mixing. The cell suspension was sonicated for a total of 5 min and centrifuged at 15000 × g for 15 min at 4 °C, and the supernatant was retained. The soluble His-tagged proteins were purified at 4 °C after binding to a Ni-NTA His-Bind resin (Sigma Chemical Co.

(St Louis, MO, USA), followed by extensive dialysis of the protein solutions against 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5 by ultra-filtration through low-adsorption hydrophilic 10k nominal molecular weight limit cutoff membranes (regenerated cellulose, Amicon) and storage at 4 °C. The proteins were further purified by gel filtration as described previously (48). Purity was assessed as >98% using SDS-PAGE analysis (49) in a Mini PROTEAN electrophoresis system (Bio-Rad). The protein concentration was determined according to Bradford with bovine serum albumin as the standard (50).

Enzyme assays for determinations of acceptor substrates. Transaminase activity was assayed using 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine and structurally diverse keto acids, aldehydes and ketones in 96-well plates as previously described with some modifications (14). Note that K2HPO4 buffer was used following recommendations described elsewhere (11,14,29).
Briefly, assay reactions were conducted as follows. Prior to the assay, a 25 mM amine donor Enzyme assays for determinations of amine substrates, including enantiopure amines.

Transaminase activity was assayed using benzaldehyde as acceptor and structurally diverse amines in 96-well plates. Any other aldehyde, ketone or keto acid may be used instead of benzaldehyde. Prior to the assay, a 25 mM acceptor benzaldehyde and 1.0 mM cofactor PLP solution was firstly prepared in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5 (40 ml). Then, a stock solution of each amine was secondly prepared in acetonitrile or buffer, depending on the solubility.

S7 and S10, most likely the positioning of the conserved Ser231 (following numeration in 3A8U), may additionally play a role in the capacity of class III ω-TA to use amines with longer alkyl substituents, to a larger extent than previously thought(28).

.5 x 22.5 cm) Petri plates with Luria Bertani (LB) agar containing chloramphenicol (12.5 g ml-1) and induction solution (Epicentre Biotechnologies; WI, USA) at a quantity recommended by the supplier to induce a high fosmid copy number. After overnight incubation at 37 °C the plates were overlaid with 40 ml of a solution of K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5 (100 mM) containing 0.4% w/v agar to which the following chemicals were added immediately prior to use: PLP (10 mg; or 1.0 mM final concentration), the amine donor 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine (202.64 mg; or 25 mM final concentration) and benzaldehyde (106.12 mg; or 25 mM final concentration) as aldehyde acceptor. Note: the method can be adapted to any other ketone or aldehyde. Positive colonies in agar plates changed to an orange/red color in 20-30 minutes, when the colonies are overlaid with the screening solution. Screens were also performed with o-xylylenediamine hydrochloride as amine donor by adapting a colorimetric assay(15). Briefly, clones were plated on LB agar containing 12.5 g ml -1 chloramphenicol (for screening clone library from environmental source) or 50 g ml -1 kanamycin (for screening P. oleovorans clone library). After overnight incubation at 37°C, clones were transferred to Whatman paper. A drop of reaction solution containing 5 mM o-xylylenediamine hydrochloride and 2.02 mM PLP in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 8.0 was placed in the lid of a Petri dish and covered with the colony-bearing Whatman paper. After sealing of the Petri dish to prevent on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from drying of the reaction solution, the plate was incubated at 30°C overnight. Positive clones with transaminase activity were identified by black coloration.

nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine and 1.0 mM cofactor PLP solution was firstly prepared in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5(40 ml). A 400 mM acceptor (keto acid, aldehyde or ketone) stock solution was secondly prepared in acetonitrile or buffer, depending on solubility. Reaction assay started by adding 2.5 µl of a protein solution (stock solution: 10.0 mg/ml in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5) to an assay mixture containing 185 µl of PLP/2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine solution and 12.5 µl of acceptor stock solution, in 96-well microtiter plates. The final volume of the assay was 200 µl, and the amine donor and acceptor concentrations were 25 mM each. All measurements were performed, if otherwise not indicated, in triplicates at 40 °C in a microplate reader at 600 nm (Synergy HT Multi-Mode Microplate Reader -BioTek) in continuous mode for a total time of 180 min. Specific activities (in U g -1 protein) were determined. One unit (U) of enzyme activity was defined as the amount of protein required to transform 1 µmol of substrate in 1 min under the assay conditions using an extinction coefficient for reaction product (aldehyde 4 in ref.(14)) of 537 M -1 cm -1 at 600 nm, as on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from determined experimentally. All values were corrected for non-enzymatic transformation (background rate).

7.5) to an assay mixture containing 185 µl of PLP/benzaldehyde solution and 12.5 µl of amine stock solution, in 96-well microtiter plates. The final volume of the assay was 200 µl, and the amine donor and acceptor concentrations were 25 mM each.Reactions were allowed to proceed for 60 min at 40 °C, during which time the remaining amount of benzaldehyde (not reacting with the amines) was determined every 5 min by adding 12.5 µl of a stock solution of the amine 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine (400 mM in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5). After adding 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine the reaction was allowed to proceed for 10 min and absorbance, due to the appearance of orange/red color, recorded continuously in a microplate reader at 600 nm (Synergy HT Multi-Mode Microplate Reader -BioTek). Lower absorbance values imply higher consumption of benzaldehyde and thus of the corresponding amines used as donors. Enzyme activity under the assay conditions was expressed as the amount of enzyme required to transform 1 µmol of substrate in 1 min under the assay conditions using an extinction coefficient for reaction product (aldehyde 4 in ref.(14)) of 537 M -1 cm -1 at 600 nm. All values were corrected for nonenzymatic transformation (background rate) and for a control reaction containing benzaldehyde but not amines (no transfer reaction occurs, so that all benzaldehyde reacts with 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine).MassSpectrometry. Conventional mass spectrometry analyses were performed on a hybrid quadrupole time-of-flight (QTOF) analyzer, model QSTAR, Pulsar I, from AB Sciex (Framingham, MA, U.S.A.). Reaction samples were analyzed by direct infusion and ionized by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) with methanol as the mobile phase in positive reflector mode. High-resolution mass spectrometry (HR-MS) analysis was carried on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from out by flow injection analysis combined with electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (FIA-ESI-MS) on a QTOF Agilent G6530A accurate mass QTOF liquid chromatographymass spectrometry (LCMS) system (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, U.S.A.). The sample was directly infused and ionized by ESI in negative reflector mode. Ionization was enhanced by JetStream technology, and the mobile phase was 99.9:0.1 (v/v) H2O/formic acid. Data were processed with Masshunter Data Acquisition B.05.01 and Masshunter Qualitative Analysis B.07.00 software (Agilent Technologies).Gas chromatography (GC) analysis for determination of chiral selectivity.Enantioselectivity was evaluated by using kinetic resolution of (R)-and (S)-amines. Prior to the kinetic resolution assay, a 25 mM acceptor benzaldehyde and 1.0 mM cofactor PLP solution was firstly prepared in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5(40 ml). A stock solution of a racemic mixture of (R)-and (S)-aminononane was secondly prepared in acetonitrile at a concentration of 400 mM each. Reaction assay starts by adding 25 µl of a protein solution (stock solution: 10.0 mg/ml in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5) to an assay mixture containing 1850 µl of PLP/benzaldehyde solution and 125 µl of racemic (R)/(S)-aminononane stock solution, in a 5.0 ml Eppendorf. The final volume of the assay was 2000 µl, and the concentration of (R)-and (S)-aminononane and benzaldehyde were 25 mM each. Reactions were allowed to proceed at 40 °C for 60 min. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered through an adsorption hydrophilic 3000 Da nominal molecular weight limit cutoff membranes (regenerated cellulose, Amicon) to remove the enzymes. Then, 10 µl of a stock solution of (R)-2-aminohexane was added as an internal standard to take into consideration biases due to the extraction procedure, performed as follows. To 0.2 ml reaction, 0.2 ml ethyl acetate was added and after vigorous vortex the solvent used for GC-MS analysis. GC system (Agilent Technologies 7890A) consisted in an auto sampler (Agilent Technologies 7693) and an inert MSD with Quadrupole (Agilent Technologies 5975). A total of 2 μL of the sample were injected through a GC-Column CP-Chirasil-Dex CB (25 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter, 0.25 μm film) (Agilent J&W GC Columns). The flow rate of the helium carrier gas, the split ratio and the temperature gradient were optimized per each of the chiral mixes.After each injection the column was cleaned up during 2 minutes at 200°C, 1.5 mL/min flow rate. The detection of each chiral compound ((R)-and (S)-aminononane)) was performed in single ion monitoring (SIM) mode in order to maximize the sensitivity. The elution order and on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from the target ions were previously validated with a standards mix and NIST 14 library. The semi-quantification of (R)-and (S)-aminononanes was performed using MassHunter Qualitative Analysis software (B.06.00, Agilent), reporting the area for the individual peaks in arbitrary units, on the basis of which enantiomeric excess and conversion were calculated. Stereochemistry was also calculated by following the asymmetric synthesis of (R)-and (S)-aminononane. Asymmetric syntheses were performed at 40 °C for 180 min in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5 containing 1 mM PLP, and 25 µg pure protein. The reaction mixture contained 25 mM 2-nonane as acceptor and 25 mM 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine as amine donor. The conversion was measured by detection of the formed amines (R)-aminononane and (S)-aminononane by GC, after extraction of the reaction products as above. The percent enantiomeric excess values for products were analyzed by GC. Note that conversions were not optimized.Enzyme assays for determinations of optimal parameters for activity. Temperatures between 25 and 70 °C were tested for the determination of the conditions under which each protein displayed maximal activity, in 100 mM K2HPO4 buffer pH 7.5. The activity in the presence of water miscible solvent was performed by adding methanol, acetonitrile, dimethyl sulfoxide, dimethyl acetamide, isopropanol and acetone at concentration from 5 to 50% (v/v). Benzaldehyde and 2-(4-nitrophenyl)ethan-1-amine were used as acceptor and as donor, respectively. The standard assay condition for determination of optimal temperature and activity in the presence of solvents was as for determinations of acceptor substrates (see above).Homology modeling and docking simulations. Homology models were developed using Prime software from Schrödinger. Prime uses BLAST (with BLOSUM62 matrix) for homology search and alignment and refines the results using the Pfam database and pairwise alignment with ClustalW. Docking simulations of (S)-(+)-2-aminononane and (R)-(-)-2-aminononane with the structural models created for each of the class III ω-TAs were carried out using the Protein Energy Landscape Exploration software, which offers one of the best modeling alternatives to map protein-ligand dynamics and induced fit, as described previously(48). The substrate was initially positioned in the active site with the nitrogen atom of the substrates towards the Lys catalytic base. The substrate conformation was set to on November 14, 2018 by guest http://aem.asm.org/ Downloaded from carried out gas chromatography analyses. RK contributed suggesting activity tests and providing substrates. MF, KEJ and PNG conceived the work. MF wrote the initial draft of the manuscript.

Genetic enzymology analysis. Sequence Similarity Networks (SSNs) were generated by EFI-EFT (51). All-vs-all BLAST was performed against the first 500 BLAST hits in UniProt (2018_06) for each query sequence (option A). A negative LogE value was applied for the initial network generation.
